This weekly bulletin informs students, parents, and staff about internships, academic
programs, jobs, leadership & community service initiatives, and other student
opportunities in a variety of fields. Please carefully note deadlines, age requirements,
and other pre-requisites for participation.
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
Service, and so on.
These various opportunities utilize different formats. Some are in-person, some
remote, and some will involve a hybrid arrangement. Check each program for their
specific format and schedule. Students should consider applying to any that match
their interests and talents.
Please note that in order to save space, many sections contain links to general
lists of related opportunities- such as for Stem programs, Community Service,
College Prep free programs, and more - be sure to click on any links that interest
you.
Here are several programs of note in this week’s bulletin from various sections; some
have rapidly-approaching deadlines:
BUSINESS: The Atlas Scholars program provides a generous scholarship & paid
summer business internships to selected students.
strong grades in STEM subjects, an interest in business/finance, and who are from an

demographic groups under-represented in finance (women, Black, Latino/a,
LGTBQ+) are encourage to attend an Information Session at Stuy (Lecture Hall A)
after 10th period on Tuesday, 1/14.
Apex for Youth offers free business-focused sessions at their downtown Manhattan
offcies, including help with resumes, interviews, networking and more from major
local companies such as Blackrock and Prudential Financial. The next session is on
January 14th. The Greenpoint YMCA in Brooklyn welcomes all students to their
upcoming free career and college readiness afterschool programs, along with free
SAT prep classes later in the spring.
And Futures & Options welcomes all students to join their
term weekly sessions, which cover many basic skills needed for business & other
internships.
LEADERSHIP/GOVERNMENT: Tne Brooklyn Distict Attorney’s office offers free
vacation week internships in law and criminal justice to all 11th and 12th graders who
livc in Brooklyn. And the Japan Society’s Junior Fellows summer program for
current 9th, 10th, and 11th grade students includes a trip to Japan!
ART/MUSEUMS: The BRIC Youth Curatorial Fellowship allows students to plan
and stage their own art exhibition with 2D and 3D mixed-media artwork at their
Brooklyn space. And The Christophers art poster contest welcomes all student art
submissions – the top prize is $1,000; several other art contests have fast-approaching
deadlines.
PARKS/NATURE: The World Conservation Society’s Discovery Guides spring term
program at local zoos and the Brooklyn Aquarium is now open to applications – all
students may apply. And Inspiring Girls is a free 12-day wilderness science
education trip for female-identifying students 16 and older.
STEM: The free Tech Scholars program at the New York Historical Society in
Manhattan combines web design lessons with research into womens’ history – all are
welcome to apply, and the deadline to do so is
All students may apply to the NASA Power to Explore Challenge, which focuses on
radioisotope energy sources for space missions. The NYU/Tandon ARISE
Engineering program is a free summer program open to current sophomores and
juniors. The Catalyst Engineering program is a free one-week summer program at
Cornell University,and is open to current 10th and 11th graders. And Step-Up is a free
summer biomedical research program for current seniors from lower-income or
onder-represented backgrounds.
WRITING/THEATER: The Summer Arts Institute (SAI) in Queens is a free, four-
week intensive arts program with training options in theater, art, music, film, dance,
and more; current 9th, 10th, and 11th grade students may apply.
The MCC Theater Youth Company Performance Lab is a free spring term
program open to students from all grades – no prior experience is necessary. Required
auditions are on January 14th.
The Asian American Journalists Association’s AAJA JCamp in Seattle is a free
one-week national multicultural journalism program open to applications from all
current 10th and 11th graders.
And the Freedom to Read spring term program at the central Brooklyn Public
Library welcomes applications from all students with an interest in intellectual
freedom and fighting censorship.
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
the Stuy community!
